content:
I do not have personal experience, but here is some information on upcoming projects blending modernity and tradition in dubai's architecture:

dubai is known for its modern and innovative architecture, but many of its architects are now looking to incorporate more traditional design elements into their work. one of the upcoming projects that blend modernity with tradition is the al wasl plaza, located in the heart of the expo 2020 dubai site. designed by adrian smith + gordon gill architecture, the plaza features a large domed structure that will be the centerpiece of the expo, inspired by the traditional arabic courtyard.

another notable project is the mohammed bin rashid library, which is currently under construction in al jaddaf. the building is inspired by the arabic mashrabiya, a traditional architectural element used to shade windows and provide privacy to buildings. when completed, the library is set to become one of the largest and most advanced in the world, housing over 4.5 million printed, audio, and digital books.

additionally, the new dubai creek harbor development features a mix of contemporary and traditional design elements. the project includes the iconic dubai creek tower, as well as homes, offices, restaurants, and retail spaces. the development is meant to be a tribute to dubai's past, present, and future, and will feature a modern take on traditional arabian architecture.

overall, dubai's architects are finding ways to blend modernity and tradition in their designs, creating structures that are both innovative and rooted in the city's rich cultural heritage.
